ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An ability to deal with primary sources and an in-depth knowledge of London.

I feel like this course helped improve my reading skills. There was a lot of very dense material that was assigned, and it was a challenge sometimes to get through all of it and be prepared to speak knowledgeably in class.
This is a great course in studying "micro-history" and using "on the ground" primary sources to learn about very particular things in very particular places.
I gained skills in evaluating time period through a cultural lens, rather than a normal chronological series of events.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course has no weaknesses - the assignments are varied and interesting, the readings were always relevant and fascinating, and Professor Wrightson creates a lovely environment during the seminar. A superb course all round.

I felt as though the reading list could have been cut down a little bit. I really liked the primary source bits of it, but I felt as though every week was a struggle to read everything for class. Professor Wrightson was definitely a highlight of the class. He is so knowledgeable about the subject, and clearly has a real passion for London. It was really fun getting to see him speak about it every week.
Great professor - very patient, kind, and enthusiastic about the material!
Strengths were excellent facilitation of discussion by the professor and engaging texts and student presentations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: A wonderful course if you are interested in London and particularly social history - you will not learn about the politics or chronological history of the time. Professor Wrightson is a wonderful, engaging professor, who fosters a nice, calm atmosphere in his seminars.

Definitely would recommend this course, but you obviously need to have an interest in the period and in English history. London may seem like a very specific topic, but theres so much to talk about just in the city alone. There's a lot of reading, but i found it all interesting, especially the primary sources. And Professor Wrightson is great. You should definitely take a class with him at some point.

I would definitely recommend this course--especially to those in the history major looking for a pre-industrial class. London is a fascinating place, and Professor Wrightson really knows what he's talking about. That said, the reading list is pretty thick. The workload is pretty light too--only a couple of short papers. Definitely glad I took this class.

Yes! This is a class in which you can simply enjoy learning and enjoy the history - the professor just wants you to be engaged with the texts and immerse yourself in individuals' lives in early modern London.

I would recommend this class and would caution students against repeating my mistakes. I really wish I had been more engaged in this seminar, because it was a comprehensive case study in cultural history, using London as an example. It wasn't always very engaging, but I absolutely could have tried harder to participate. This is a class where you get as much out of it as you put in.
I would. It caters to quite a specific interest, but if early modern Europe appeals to you, this is pretty much the best class you could take. Really pleasant.
